text:
Hi, I'm Chris Manning here to answer your 
questions on artificial intelligence. [Music]

Let's see what I've got. [Question] What are foundation 
models and how are they useful?

[Manning] "Foundation  models" is a
term we coined at Stanford to characterize the class of huge new
artificial intelligence neural network

models that have been released recently
and are so influential. But the idea was
   that the same idea of having models that
were just trained by seeing a ton of

data from the world could be applied, not
only to language, but also to vision,

genomic sequences, robotics, other signals
like radar, and that by having large,

large, large neural networks see an
enormous amount of data they can get to
   understand a lot about the world and a
lot about human languages if it's human

language data. These foundation models
now give us computer models with
   much more understanding which are being
widely deployed and reinventing what we

can do with artificial intelligence.
[Question] How is AI limited by hardware, energy

consumption, the cost of LLMs and what
can be done about it? [Manning] Good question.

I think you can turn around the first part
of it and say that a large part of the

dramatic recent advances in AI have been
powered by great increases in the amount

of available hardware and the amount of
available data. And yes, that does use

quite a bit of energy but it's really
having these powerful parallel
   processing chips ,GPUs, and lots and lots
of digital online data that have

allowed us to do so much in artificial
intelligence. I mean, as to what can be

done about it, well people are hard at
work on all the different dimensions of

this so absolutely people would like to
design better processors that require

less energy. Beyond that I mean there's a
lot of work that's been done by the big

cloud providers to get renewable
energy sources for their data centers.

So, you know, overall even though these
systems do use significant amounts of
   energy they're really not as bad as
taking your international plane flights

for your vacation. As to how we can build
models that use less compute and less

data, you know a brain uses extremely
little power, right. You know, we run on

way less than an LED light bulb. It
suggests that as well as working out

better computer technologies at the
hardware level what we should be trying

to work out is better ways of doing
machine learning that can learn more

with less data. It seems very clear
that human babies can learn

significantly more from a limited amount
of data than our machine learning models  yet can. But you know, that means there's
still exciting things to do in

artificial intelligence research.
Let's see... [Question] How can we improve

explainability of AI models? [Manning] That's a
question that many people have been
   interested in. There are two sides to
that. You know, one side is to say that

perhaps it's okay to have AI models
that aren't explainable providing they

do the right thing. You know, after all,
humans make lots of decisions and a lot

of the time they can't really explain
why they thought one way or the other.

It was their hunch or the sixth sense that, it
felt like this thing wasn't genuine.

But, you know nevertheless, there are lots
of contexts, whether it's in legal
   contexts or medical contexts where
you'd like to have explanations and so

there's a lot of work in trying to make
models more explainable and I think
   there are two fundamental levels at
which that happens. At a low level you

want to be able to interrogate a neural
network and decide which features of an
   input are causing it to make a certain
decision. And there's plenty of work

that's doing that. so there are methods
like LIME that was pioneered by Carlos Guestrin here at Stanford that are
looking at those kinds of explainability

in your networks. But I think a lot of
the time, once we move to very large
   neural networks we'd like a higher level
of explainability, that the neural

network can actually just tell us why it
is making a certain decision. And I think

that's a capability that we're actually
approaching with large language models--
   that large language models can often
give a quite good explanation

as to what are the features that
lead them to certain decisions.
   OK. [Question] In the future will AI be
so smart it won't need human input?

[Manning] That's a good question and I think the
honest answer is no one knows. There is a

conceivable world at some point in the
distant future where an AI system can

just learn everything it needs from the
world around it and it doesn't really

need us to tell it things. But I think
there's also a lot of very heated hype

at the moment. You can see lots of
predictions that artificial general
   intelligence is just around the corner.
Some people think that by 2030

there'll be computers that are better
than human beings at almost all tasks.

I think a lot of those views are fairly
irrational exuberance, where people

have been getting a little bit too
excited by the very genuine big advances
   we made in the last few years. They have,
if you will, drunk a little too much of

their own Kool-Aid. So, on the one hand
there's no doubt at all there have been

really exciting advances and there are
many ways that computers such as large

language models that have ingested just
huge amounts of text, you know billions

of web pages, all of Wikipedia, just know
a lot more than humans do. But there are

other ways in which humans' knowledge and
ability to operate in the world is
   likely to be better than our AI models
for a number of decades to come.

OK. [Question] I've completed the basics of
machine learning and deep learning, what
   should I learn next? [Manning] I don't think
that's a question that has a one-size

fits all answer. I mean you know, one
answer is that maybe you should apply

some of the knowledge that you have
learned. I mean, I think it's just a great

next step to find a project that's
something that you're really interested
   in. It could be something at work or it
could just be something that's

completely an interest of yours as a
hobbyist thing---working out something for
   you know, rating wines or something.
So you know spending more time actually

building an AI application from
beginning to end is still a huge

further learning exercise after doing
one or two of our classes. But there are
   lots of other great classes you could do
and I think at that point it depends

more on what you're interested in. So for
example, you know if you're interested in

human languages do the my natural
language processing course. On the

other hand, if you're more interested in
robotics say and ideas as to how you can

have robots respond to events in the
world then maybe you want to do the
   reinforcement learning course. If you're
interested in something like

relationships between genes and drugs
and proteins,
   well maybe that's graph neural networks as
the next step. I think you really need to

think about what would be useful and
interesting to you.
   OK. [Question] Will conversational assistants 
and chat bots replace search engines?

{Manning] That's a very  topical 
question and I think there isn't a single answer. I think search is actually a a multifaceted
thing and there are different answers

for different kinds of searches. So
maybe I can choose three cases. One case

is that people just have a particular
question in mind... So my question is, you

know, whatever it is... when is the primary
going to be held in the elections for

California, or who is Beyonce married to
or something like that. Well you know, to  the extent that I've got a question like
that, yeah absolutely I think we're

already at the point right now where
conversational agents LLMs are great

for that sort of purpose, that they're
faster and better than something else you could use. You can also use them for
all kinds of other question-answering

related purposes some that you might not
expect. So you know. if you're looking for a hotel recommendation for your next
trip to Oregon you know actually you can

do that very well if you just like to be
suggested a hotel that a model thinks would be good for you. But there are also
a lot of other ways that people use

search. So sometimes people use search
when they want to take a deep dive themselves, right. You know they're buying
a new tent and they'd like to read you

know 20 pages of reviews of different
tents by outdoor enthusiasts to make up

their own mind. Well to the extent that
that's what you want to do, no you want to use a search engine that can give you
a list of pages that' be good things

to read about reviews of hiking. And then
a third case that's actually surprisingly common is what people in
search just refer to as navigational

queries. You know there are lots of
cases where people are making a search

like "Honda Odyssey" where they just want
to be taken to the page about the Honda Odyssey to read about it. So it's not
really searching for information, it's

really just wanting to be navigated to a
web page and that's obviously not going to be covered by using a large
language model. Perhaps a better example

of that is when you want to do something
transactional like I want to, you

know, check my bank balance and I just
put Chase Bank into the search engine

because it's just easier than typing the
URL. OK. [Question] What motivates you despite the

hype and occasional negative comments?
Well I think that one has a really easy answer which is is that this has been
just such an exciting time in artificial

intelligence. I've been involved in
artificial intelligence for about 30 years and all through that time have had
a feeling that, yes we've been making

progress, there have been scientific
advances, there have been new ideas for how to build systems, typical gradual
scientific progress. But the reality was

that the for the majority of that time
systems didn't work that well, progress

was kind of slow, there weren't really
applications that were good enough for human beings to use for many purposes.
In contrast, the pace in the last 5 years

has just been astounding. It seems
like, you know, every month or two there's

some dramatic new advance in systems and
their quality. We have amazing language

models that do such a good job of
answering questions. There's been rapid

progress in generative AI for doing
things like creating images. We're starting to see that even generative
video is becoming possible. Great work

has been done in understanding the
structure and folding of proteins using artificial intelligence. Lots of other
applications in all kinds of places, so

there's just been this huge amount of
optimism and excitement from everything that we can now do and the whole world
has become excited by some of these

things. I certainly don't want to deny
that there's hype around artificial intelligence. There's a lot of hype at
the moment of people making very strong

and wild claims of how fantastic things
are or how fantastic they'll be in 3

years time, but this isn't a hype
machine--this is something where there's

exuberance on top of a field that really
is making dramatic advances. So I focus

on those dramatic advances and it's easy
to stay optimistic. Now there's also

considerable concerns about artificial
intelligence. There's concerns about the systems, as to whether they're biased
against different groups such as

different ethnic groups. There's concern
about whether the systems will have bad

effects such as that people will lose
their jobs to AI systems. And furthest out

some people beat a drum where they're
saying that these AI systems will become

so intelligent and good that they'll be
a danger to humans. I think those are

different problems and they're all
important to think about but they have

different responses. So relative to
the question of AI systems being biased

in various ways, that's a really genuine
concern but it's also an opportunity

for research. So there's considerable
research work now including at Stanford

by some of my colleagues such as
Tatsu Hashimoto on how can you design

different kinds of learning algorithms
which suffer less from the tendency of

being biased to work only for the
majority subpopulation of a population.

So hopefully a lot of those things can be
at least lessened in time with improved

data and improved machine learning. The
problem of some people losing jobs is a

serious and a real one. I mean that's
happened throughout time going back to you know a period where nearly everybody
worked the land and gradually there

started to be more automation on
farms. So I think, you know, it can be

difficult for individuals when their
jobs change--they have to learn new things, they perhaps even have to train
for a different job. But I think that's

been the nature of the advancement of
humanity and society as well and so the

main pressure there is on trying to make
it easy for people to find new roles in

a changing world. Then there are some
people that do what some people call

criti-hype, of greatly hyping these
super intelligent science fiction AIs

that somehow are going to develop the
goal of wiping out humanity. I think

that's unrealistic on a couple of levels.
Firstly I think we're a very, very long

way from having the technology for any
such thing. You know, we still just don't

have very good robotics technology for
things to move around the world and control things the way that
human beings do so fluently. But beyond

that I mean there just absolutely no
reason to think a computer has any

particular reason to wipe out a human
being, that our computer systems just

don't have the same basal evolutionary
strategies of, you know, competing for

food in a human world. So I think
there's a lot of projection and fantasy

there and I don't actually think that
that's something we need to worry about a great deal. OK. [Question] What's the next big thing
after large language models?

[Manning] There's
an easy answer to that and then there's a hard version of that question. The easy
answer is to say, well the technology of

large language models, which is
essentially, we could take a piece of

text, blank out some amount of it, and
then say given the start of the sentence what will the next word be, try and
predict it, learn if you get it wrong and

then just repeat over billions of times. That strategy of what is sometimes called
"unsupervised learning" or sometimes

"self-supervised learning" since you're
sort of making your own learning game, you can repeat that strategy in other
areas. So you can take a picture and

blank out bits of it and try to predict
what's in the part that's missing. You can take a gene sequence and blank out a
piece of it and try and predict it. So

this is then a very successful strategy
that can be used for all sorts of other

domains of human experience and science
and that leads to the generalization

that we call foundation models. So we're
going to see a lot of broader use of foundation models in the soon nearby
years. But there's a harder version of

that question which is to say if large
language models aren't everything you

need for artificial intelligence what
else do you need and how can you

successfully build it? Most people think
you are going to need some other things, that even though large language models
have been incredibly successful they

don't really seem to build the kind of
world models that human beings have

where they have a sense of stuff in a
physical world and particular entities

(human beings, corporations) and their
relations that's more abstracted away

from particular sequences of words. And
so that suggests we need some kind of

different model of artificial
intelligence that allows us to build that successfully and I that's
something that, you know, people are

absolutely working on and you know
people have been looking at things like graph neural networks but I think it's fair
to say no one really knows the answer of

how to do that successfully and so
that's why we're still doing academic research. [Question} How do I increase my
understanding of AI beyond off-the-shelf packages?
[Manning] I've got the answer to that one:  You have to build things. It's a

really good learning experience to
actually work on building things for

yourself. I mean many of the most capable
AI practitioners just put effort into

building things for themselves,
reimplementing things. You know, one great

example of that is the Stanford PhD
grad is Andrej Karpathy. So Andrej has had

a career, first working at Tesla and now
he's back at open AI, but you know he's

also just a weekend hacker who
likes to build things. So you know just

recently he's written a sort of a
little implementation of large language

models, a mini GPT, you know completely
from scratch. And the reality is that

just by building things for yourself
from scratch, even if they replicate

something that someone has done or a big
framework from a tech company, you just learn so much and that's always a great
exercise to work through.

OK [Question] Will classical AI and machine
learning algorithms be usable in the age

of quantum computing? [Manning] That's a hard
one. I'm really not an expert on quantum

computing but honestly, at the moment I
see no danger at all of quantum

computing capabilities displacing
what we're doing in AI and machine learning. At the moment people are
still struggling to build really small

quantum computers so those really small
quantum computers can be used for things

like cryptography and the fear is that,
because of their different nature, then

they can break the kind of cryptography
that we all depend on at the moment both to keep you know our banking
transactions and government secrets

secure. But you can only build small
quantum computers and precisely all the

action at the moment in artificial
intelligence is building huge neural networks. So our quantum computers
are, you know, a million times

smaller than the kind of neural networks
we're building now and they appear to be very difficult to scale. So I think
there's sort of no foreseeable future

where quantum computing really changes
or stops what we're doing in artificial intelligence. OK. [Question] What are some
promising new career paths within

[Manning] So there are lots! We're still
at a stage in which there's just a huge

shortage of machine learning engineers
and a huge shortage of people with a good understanding of neural networks,
natural language processing, and robotics

and related technologies. So that if you
get good skills in these areas there are

all sorts of things that you can do. One
caution: it's hard to know what will

happen in the coming years. But you know
clearly the very biggest tech companies

have had a certain bit of indigestion
over the last year or two that for a while they were hiring up every machine
learning engineer they could find, often

paying them humongous salaries, and then
they've decided that oh gee maybe we

have been just hiring people
because they're available and we thought we should try and corner the market and
so they've really pulled back on

hiring in AI but also in other areas. But
you know the flip side of that is

there's every other kind of industry
whether you're thinking something like other players in the car industry, people
in banking and finance, people in

construction, people who like to automate
mining or agriculture. Anywhere you look

there are lots of applications now
where there are ways that you could use

artificial intelligence to reinvent
different industries and nearly none of

those have been explored and built. And
so I think there's just an endless need for and opportunities for people
using machine learning. In my spare

time I also do some advising of
companies and you sort of sort of see that in all sorts of places, right. So
there are little startups using deep

learning for weather prediction. They're
using deep learning to predict better diets for cows so they don't burp so
much and release so much methane into

the atmosphere,
doing robotics having drones flying

around factories so you can monitor
the levels of different supplies without

human beings needing to run around the
factories. You know everywhere you can think of places where we can now have
more automation and that's going to be

using artificial intelligence
technologies. [Question] What are some key

challenges in the field of natural
language processing? [Manning] In some ways that's become a harder question than it was a few
years ago because large language models

were the first huge success of this new
style of self-supervised learning that

we're doing and sometimes even to me it
almost feels like natural language

processing is solved that a lot of the
things that I used to spend all my time

doing not very successfully such as
getting information out of text

documents, you know, finding facts like
for some company you know how much pollution did they
release what was their profit or loss,

who's their CEO. That getting
things like facts out of documents used

to be just extremely difficult to do
well whereas a lot of the time now you

can use large language models and they
just work fantastically well and it seems like we can do natural language.
But you know the reality is that that's

still very partial. I mean we have sort
of sort of working machine translation

for large widely spoken languages but
you know there's still opportunities for it to get better. But you know also there
are a lot of things that are

harder in machine translation as soon as
you move away from English, Chinese,

Hindi, German. You're moving
into a lot of smaller languages whether it's smaller European languages like you
know Danish or Swedish or smaller

languages from other parts of the world
an African language like Sesotho or smaller

Indian language like Marathi or something
like that. I mean, for none of those languages are there good machine
translation systems and it's harder to

build them because there's much less
data available. When it comes to doing

things of generating text, you know if
you just want to generate text that

reads fluently you can do it really well
now, but if you're wanting to generate

text or indeed to generate images that
express a particular point in a particular way we still have not as much
control as we'd like to have.

For building conversational systems,
maintaining an understanding of both the

person you're talking to in their
context we're still not very good at that content maintenance either. And then
there are lots of the problems that we

were talking about earlier; things like
bias in large language models, explainability of large language models,
so there are still tons of different

areas to address in the future. I'll just
finish with one interesting new direction that some students are
working on at Stanford which is how do

we build the next level up from large
language models. So if you're actually going to be building full applications
with large language models it normally

just isn't going to be the case that
you've got one large language model and you're done. You're actually going to
build lots of components around your

large language model because maybe
there's going to be one large language model that generates some ideas for a
story, there's going to be another large

language model that generates a script
based on that that'll be interrogated by a third model which checks to see if
there's gender bias and if so revises

it. So you're actually sort of building a
program out of large language models and

that's an exciting new higher level
domain that we're just beginning to explore. Here are a couple of AI-
generated questions.

[Question] Considering the rapid progress
in NLP what key factors and actions

should the community prioritize for
responsible and ethical AI language model deployment and development?
[Manning] Well it's really good to know

that the AI systems are also thinking about what's
important for responsible and ethical AI

language model deployment. So there are
lots of things to think about there.

We certainly want systems that don't
exhibit conventional gender biases or

ethnic stereotypes and the fact of the
matter is that all of the current large language models do exhibit those
problems. It's a combination of two

things: in part it's because these models
are just trained on a lot of historical

data from the world and, well, what they
see is that nearly all politicians in the United States are white males and so
they developed the stereotype that a

politician is a white male. You know, one
of the things that human beings are better at is having in their head how
they think the world should be rather

than just knowing how the world has been
and having statistics based on that. But there are also details of the machine
learning models where they tend to

emphasize majority cases and forget
about the minority cases so we should be

working out how to build models that do
a better job of that. But we should also be trying to get data from
different sources so it represents

different groups and we should have the
preferences of different groups involved

in the evaluation of models finding
their weak spots, teaching them how to

behave. So a couple of people at Stanford
have been involved in this idea of jury

learning (Professor Michael Bernstein
and his students) and the idea there is

that there isn't sort of one right
answer to how you should behave in many contexts, that different subgroups of
people have different Impressions and

so you actually want to represent a jury
of your peers and how different people feel about things. And for some things
you want to be sensitive to minorities

and their interests even if the majority
of people don't find something offensive

or minded and so lots of things to
explore in those areas.

OK, AI system asks... [Question] What are some of the
most promising and exciting real world

applications of NLP that you foresee
emerging in the next few years?

[Manning] Ah tons! So I think we're going
to see a lot more NLP systems being

deployed very successfully everywhere. So
a lot of websites already have a little

AI assistant in the bottom corner
where you can chat to the AI assistant

about the company product or things like
that. At the moment they sort of work but they're not really that great or at
least I don't find them that great. I

think we're going to see a new
generation of ones powered by large language models which really work much
more fluently. I think we're going to

see much more use of conversational
assistants. I mean, some people think it's

a horrible prospect to imagine people
talking to an AI assistant rather than

another human being and I'm
not one to say that we don't want humans talking to human beings, of course we do.
We need much more community than we have

in the current modern world, but it turns
out that there are lots of people who would like to get feedback from somebody
or something that can give humanlike

responses and don't always have the right 
human beings standing by.  So you're thinking
about how to word an email to your

boss or you're not quite sure what you
should say to your boyfriend... It turns

out that you can get advice, drafting
help, suggestions of what to say from a large language model that are actually
useful these days. But you know once

you move out from there I think kind of
there are all sorts of job functions

which now a large language model can
help you with and I think most of us

just haven't thought enough about
what the models could do. So you know,

next time if you've got some writing
assignment, you know, whether you're wanting to post a job advertisement or
write your monthly status report,

I encourage you to try it out.
Rather than trying to write it all for yourself from a blank page. Maybe just
write six bullet points and say "hey

large language model, can you write a
monthly status report around these

points" and I think you'll be surprised
at how good it comes out. To take one more example, my colleague at Stanford
who does bioinformatics, Anshul,

recently reported that he just
took a vacation to Europe with his kids

and the way he found all the hotels to
stay at in Europe was by asking a large

language model for recommendations and
he was amazed at how good the recommendations were. And when things
went wrong on the plans for the trip,

because you know kids they do different
things and they might be tired or not want to do stuff, he asked the large
language model, gee what could I do

instead this afternoon, and he liked the
answers he got. You know I'd honestly  never contemplated doing that.
I went on a vacation this

summer as well and I did the
conventional old way of doing searches, looking at websites, etc. You know, I
think there's just a whole world of ways

that we can use these models because our
world is so language-based and that

we're all just sort of exploring what
some of the possibilities are.
[Music]
